text:
Call it the sweet revenge of Daniel Dae Kim. Perhaps best known as Chin Ho on CBS’s Hawaii Five-0, Kim, along with co-star Grace Park, left the show after producers controversially refused to give the actors equal pay to their Caucasian co-stars.

But it seems Kim wasn’t standing still and his principled position left time to concentrate on other projects that allowed for a giant measure of retribution, Hollywood-style. The Korean-American actor, who first rose to stardom in J.J. Abrams’ survivalist drama Lost, had long been fond of the weepy but compelling soap operas that are a staple in his native land. He decided to take a chance and optioned a popular series that debuted in 2013 about an autistic young doctor trying to navigate his way through his first job at a hospital. The plot didn’t seem a likely fit with American network television. Moreover, apart from the long-standing Grey’s Anatomy, hospital dramas since the halo era of George Clooney in ER were no longer in vogue.

ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW

Which makes The Good Doctor one of this television season’s most intriguing success stories. It underlines the big-money politics of creating a hit in the era of peak television where perseverance, talent, the burden of race and not a little luck can make or break a show. And the story also has a key Canadian connection in showrunner David Shore, who adapted the series for American audiences. In his first attempt as an executive producer, Kim produced a massive hit right out the gate. Or perhaps more appropriately in the afterglow of the Olympics in Pyeongchang, the rookie scored pure television gold. The show is the most watched drama on network TV. In Canada, it beats out other highly hyped drama juggernauts such as This Is Us. In recent ratings it was the fourth most watched show in Canada after the Academy Awards, Big Bang Theory and Young Sheldon. The season finale airs Monday at 10 p.m. on CTV. “At this point I couldn’t be happier,” says the soft-spoken Kim, 49, in an interview. “I realize how difficult it is to get any show on the air, let alone one as successful as this one. I’ve been knocking on wood every day.” But Kim says the show really started to develop quickly with the input of London, Ontario’s Shore, who viewers may remember from the last medical series he created, House starring Hugh Laurie as the acerbic Dr. Gregory House.

The Good Doctor “didn’t strike me as a Korean show that I could turn into an American show. It struck me as a good universal story,” says Shore, 58, in an interview. “It’s an amazing thing that people really tell stories in very similar ways. We are not as different as we think.” “I had never seen a character living with autism on American TV. The humanity of those characters on the Korean show was what I was interested in, not just living with autism,” says Kim. “He was a three-dimensional human being, not a polemic. And I was lucky to be working with David, who really put everything into focus. When we brought him on board that’s when it became a competitive situation.”
